Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Lhasa Block Top to Bottom--Lithospheric Evolution of Asia's Leading Edge
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Himalaya?Tibet orogenic system has been the subject of extensive research for decades, and continues to be a fruitful laboratory for understanding orogenic processes and continental evolution. Geological and geophysical studies have provided important insights into the structure and dynamics of the modern system, but imparted less information about the orogen?s early development, and the characteristics of the colliding continents that may affect subsequent evolution. The goal of this project is to investigate how crustal and lithospheric thickness changes in southern Tibet in order to establish the ?boundary conditions? for the India-Eurasia collision (~50 My ago) and how lithosphereic thickness changes during and after collision. As pointed out by the PIs, lithospheric thickness defines the thermal state and rheology of the crust and lithosphere, which are important boundary conditions and properties necessary for understanding the nature of crustal and lithospheric deformation during collision.

The PIs will integrate geochemistry, geochronology, paleoelevation, seismology, tectonics, and modeling to understand the pre-collision structure and evolution of the leading edge of the southern Asian continental margin ? the Lhasa block ? and its role in controlling the development of the broader orogen. They seek to answer two sets of related questions:

? How has the crustal thickness of the Lhasa block evolved from collision to the present?
? How have the elevation and denudation histories changed through time?
? What role does metamorphism play in altering crustal rheology and density and as a consequence facilitate surface uplift and erosion?
? What is the contribution of lithospheric deformation to thickening of the region?

This set of questions is relevant because of the way crustal thickness and surface elevation can influence the mechanics of an orogen.

The second set of related questions addresses the later evolution of the Lhasa block:

? What is the origin of post-collisional magmas?
? To what extent has melting contributed to crustal weakening and flow?
? How have magmatic and aqueous fluids and lateral heterogeneity in their distribution influenced evolution and deformation of the Lhasa block?
? Why are elevations in the Lhasa block relatively uniform despite considerable variations in geology, exhumation, and deep structure?

The importance of these questions derives from the control that rheology and its spatial
variations play in determining how orogens deform at large and small scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Lhasa Block is an important geologic element in the large Himalaya-Tibet region, which has experienced the outcomes of some 50 million years of collision between two tectonic plates. This collision was preceded by an extended period of plate convergence that produced a continental margin in southern Tibet perhaps similar to the modern Andean margin. The Lhasa Block effectively represents this sort of geologic setting, and as such its geologic history records the entire Himalayan mountain-building event. This makes the Lhasa Block a valuable natural laboratory for studying the process of continental collision at different stages of development and assessing the evolution of such important parameters as crustal thickness, past topographic elevation, and the flow of crustal and lithospheric mass through processes such as extrusion, erosion, melt redistribution, and thickening of mantle and crustal lithosphere. Such parameters in turn can have significant impacts on a much broader region due to the way they alter the stress field around the collision as well as control distribution of mass.

The Lehigh University component of this project focused on the timing of erosional and deformational events as well as the nature of landscape evolution, and seismic assessment of deeper lithospheric structure and composition. This work involved thermochronology and broadband seismology as its tools, and was carried out by collaborative teams of Ph.D. students and faculty across several institutions and internationally.

Intellectual Merit. By looking at the cooling history of crustal rocks using temperature-sensitive dating tools (thermochronology) we were able to document over the long term the amounts and patterns of erosional removal of material over the history of the Lhasa Block, finding that there are strong gradients in the timing and especially the amounts of erosion, ranging from little to no erosion in points to the NW of Lhasa, to up to 20 km of erosion within the past 20 million years in southeasternmost regions. We were able to document rapid and sudden changes in exhumation rates within the past 10-15 million years, and also document the incision history of the Yarlung Tsangpo into the southernmost Lhasa Block ? these latter two findings have important bearing on how the younger Himalayan mountain belt evolved because of the important of erosion in influencing rock deformation and also due to potential feedbacks between uplift of rock, creation of topography, diversion of rainfall, and the tectonic control of river networks.

Our work in seismology focused on an integrated effort to determine crustal thickness using published data. This work mapped out considerable variations in current crustal thickness in the Lhasa Block and can be integrated with other measurements carried out by this project in assessing the history of topographic elevation, geochemically determined crustal thickness, and removal of material by erosion. An additional finding from seismology was that significant parts of the southern Lhasa Block contain high-velocity material in the lower crust, probably produced by high-pressure metamorphism if Indian-plate crust as it underthrusts the Himalaya and arrives below Tibet. Such ?eclogite? can have significant impacts on the behavior of crustal deformation and the development of topographic elevation. Additionally, owing to logistical issues with seismometer deployment in Tibet, through an NSF-approved modification to this award, we deployed a number of broadband instruments in Mongolia to assess the enigmatic deformation and growth of topography evident there, some of which has been attributed to dynamics that are in part associated with the India-Asia collision in the broadest sense.

Broader Impacts. Our work contributed to the intellectual infrastructure in earth sciences by providing fundamental geophysical and geochronological data from two remote locations that are important in understanding how continents evolve, and our measurements tested ideas about how such evolution occurs. Our results and conclusions have been reported in journal articles, and at scientific meetings and workshops. This project supported the academic and research training of two Ph.D. students (one of whom is female), a female M.S. student, and two undergraduates. The students also obtained experience with field work in international locations. Finally, all project members gained experience in international cooperation with colleagues and peers in China and Mongolia.
